title: I hope Riot has learned valuable lessons from season 6, 7, and 8
body:
This isn't a "shit on Riot post," and I actually think Riot has done tons of stuff of value in the last few years of League. That being said, basically every friend I had who played League with me since seasons 1-2 quit around Worlds patch of season 7. I still find playing alone pretty fun, but I desperately wish all my irl friends would return to League. Unfortunately when games lose players it's monumentally difficult to get them back.

The practices of season 6 (which went a little into 7) have basically been nixed. Ever since the disastrous Juggernaut patch class updates game every few months, basically always failing at their intended impact. Without the full VGU treatment lots of people felt it was unjustified that their champions got changed as well, and the balance impacts of reworking so many people at once lasted for years and still have impacts in many cases today. 

In season 7, Riot basically outright refused to balance the game. Ardent Censor was added at the start of the year and was pretty crazy, was tinkered with slightly around midseason and that's also when everyone discovered it was actually batshit insane. Because Worlds was still MONTHS AWAY (aka soon apparently), Riot refused to change the item because they said it was too soon to 7.18. This was what broke my friends' will to play, and almost got me. The outright refusal to change anything when the game was dominated by bottom lane was clear favoritism for both the lane and for flashy bottom plays for pro play.

In season 8, Riot has taken the opposite approach of the previous season. Everything has changed every few patches this year to the point it is nauseating. A lot of it seems to be change for the sake of change, basically taking turns ruining every role. Mages got shafted, tanks got shafted, junglers not named Graves got shafted, bot got shafted, then fighters got shafted when their items were cancelled. I don't think Riot sat on a lot of these changes long enough. The universal dislike of the scuttle changes makes me wonder how the hell that patch was greenlit, bottom lane has more class diversity but only a handful of picks from each viable bot class can even be played and other people like crit ADCs are just being deleted. The rune changes at the start of the season should have been the primary balancing point, and I actually really like Runes Reforged because the old stat-based runes were boring and felt archaic to me, but rather than balancing the OP runes Riot went right into the big patch every month and midseason has gone by. Basically a bunch of things that need to be tweaked have stocked up and right now the game feels very gimmicky. Nothing wrong with diversity but Heimerdinger/Fiddle and Swain/Pyke feel very bullshit and unfun to play against.

Basically what I'm saying is that I think from now on, Riot needs to play whack a mole with balance until the game feels good again. Refusing to balance made the game boring and everyone left, then balancing it too hard every single patch has made it impossible for returning and new players to get back into the game. Preseason is a fine time to turn the meta on its head but considering the meta has been shifting wildly monthly this year I honestly think Riot just needs to stabilize the game and let it rest a while, while STILL balancing the crazy strategies unlike in season 7. I'll probably be playing this game for years to come still but I can't deny that my friends quitting and overall fatigue with my champions being deleted or brought to godly levels every few patches is just... too much. I find myself playing less or less, not necessarily because I don't want to play but because player retention has been nonexistent and the game itself is volatile. League is almost definitely my favorite game and I want to see it continue. For that we need a solid and stable release schedule, with enough changes to feel worthwhile but not so many that the game basically explodes in all directions with crazy op new strats every patch that take months to be reigned in.

Similar to how laners balance their champion according to how they play their lane. If you know you can't win the early levels, or easily lose them, you play back do your best to farm and survive. The problem is that riot redesigned their game to be incapable of shifting without oversight. Previously the game had enough depth and complexity that, if left alone for a few months, the meta would shift on its own as players started to figure out necessary counter measures to lock down something that is OP. The game is just to shallow for that to happen now, which results in riot needing to walk a thin line between changing everything too often and letting too many of the problems fester. 

They defined so many of the play styles and created such a power gap between intended play and unintended play, that when something gets OP, there's no amount of niche counter picking that can actually successfully counter the OP thing without completely throwing the core objectives. Riot themselves have to step in to resolve the issue or provide an explicit counter.

I don't want to hate on CertainlyT, but the leniency and positive feedback he gets from actually breaking the established rules of the game aren't helping riot, because they've blatantly caused a significant amount of the power creep (of all forms) to occur. 
Though it doesn't help that riot also seems to have no issues with removing things, or champions, which have the potential to act as the niche hard counters when a champion gets out of hand... {{champion:90}} {{item:3140}} 

Riot fucked up, but it's not the kind of fuck up that happened because of patch X.Y, it's the kind of fuck up that took years to build up and is now a colossal mess. They built the game up so much, but did so without regard for how the next layer could be supported and without periodically reinforcing the old layers. And no reinforcing the old layers doesn't mean swapping them out because you can't think of how to make the new shit work based on how the old layer is designed. If you've got that kind of conflict occurring, then you've clearly built far too off center and the correction needs to be made on the design of the new content not the old. The old evidently works, and while it's necessary to go back with a fresh coat of paint periodically, you can't change the base without taking down the whole building, intentionally or otherwise.

This is actually the biggest problem. Everything is optimized around intended highs, and odd or unorthodox power combinations are usually nerfed because they get in the way of those intended "optimal play" highs.

I even have a direct example. I had a specific Sion runepage for dealing with people who play incredibly aggro champs and constantly try to fight. Instead of trying to fight them back, I made a page with a combination of flat armor and HP regen. In the end I had 7 hp/sec at the start of the game.  I gave up any offensive stats from runes or masteries for it. I made a tradeoff to use a different strategy than my opponent and beat them that way. Now the only real strategy is "fight them better" which isn't actually strategy, thats just outplaying.

So I won't lie, I actually like that new champions break the rules of the game and add new mechanics. I've played and own every champion in the game, and at this point big VGUs and new releases are the most exciting thing for me. Sometimes they come out imbalanced and once they are in the hands of the balance team rather than the team who created them they either get ruined or stay insane, which is more indicative of the balance team than anything to me. Assassins will always get hate 100% of the time from the boards because they're not fun to play against, but honestly new Akali looks exciting to me as someone who plays every lane and every role. I can't blame a designer for numbers being screwy after the champ is out of their hands.

As for Stormrazor, yeah I agree. Frontloading ADC damage should have never been an idea in the first place, especially with guaranteed crits one item into your build that also gives AS. ADC is supposed to be a sustained damage source when they are powered on, but Stormrazor is basically an admission that an insane punch has to be thrown up front for a champ to be viable.

It also shouldn't stack with Duskblade. I think Duskblade is justified despite the hate because it's meant for assassins who are the up front punch class, maybe the ward killer passive is a bit overtuned though. I honestly think they should've made Stormrazor an item that works like Ashe's passive, where ADCs can opt into cutting their crit damage by spreading it out over all their attacks.

I just left this as it's own comment, but i'll reiterate it here.

This isn't a maintainable design. It will work for some time, but as you start to move too off center, to the point that the core design of the game can't support this breaking of the rules. Then one has to give. 
Either the old or the new. 
But the old is what gave you the flexibility to build the new, if that gives, everything comes down. If the new gives, it's a setback, but not unmanageable. I think that riot fails to considered how much these issues have been stacking up and went unresolved, simply because they were within the bounds of flexibility that the game had.

In many ways assassins shouldn't exist from a design prospective, but they can if you have the proper foundational design to support them, which the game doesn't still. It'd make more sense to split the community, if the large chunk of the edges can't coexist, then you've either got to accept losing them or split the community to accommodate both independently.

Well, let's take this all in retrospect.  (And incidentally the lessons could go back a few seasons further.)  

The Ardent meta made supports actually useful and feel like they had a role in the game (unlike the Locket meta in season 5 which basically turned supports into a "use active on single item and wait about 90 seconds" before the support was useful again).

The fourth season had metas all over the place - the only thing consistent then was change.  Tanks had a place.  Assassins had a place.  There were overpowered champs (Lucian, Oriana, etc.).  There was even an odd support at mid meta (Soraka, Lulu, Karma).  

Season 3 can be summed up in one item: {{item:3071}} .  This was, I think, the first real sign that balancing the game in any form is truly difficult - especially when one item can really ruin the quality of overall play.

Season 2 was the "let's break the sustain" meta or "we need a jungle" meta.  Lots of "square pegs in round holes" to borrow the metaphor.  

And so on.

Regardless, what we as players must realize is that if one player is going to be happy with the current state of the game (not using the term meta here), then another will be absolutely annoyed.  A group of people right now want "botlane diversity" so they can play their Darius and Garen in botlane -when it will inconvenience a bunch of other players who want to play their Jinx and Miss Fortune.  (Not using Lucian or Vayne because it seems that those players will play them anywhere anyhow ).

The game itself is a complex entity - any one change can have emergent properties that the devs didn't consider.  Even though I am not happy with the state of the botlane right now as a support main, I know that any attempts to undo the mess that was created over the last 7-8 patches(!) is going to take a long, long time to undo.

Currently we can assume that the devs are basically taking steps to speed up the games - to compete with Overwatch, PubG, Battle Royale, Realm Royale and Fortnite.  Sadly, their ability to communicate their intentions and the consequences of their actions has been poor.  No, "thanks for sticking with us as we do X, Y and Z" - but instead some weak patch notes, some videos that don't outright tell us what they are trying to do, and attempts in pro league streams to sugarcoat everything and make it appear that everything is alright.

In short, Riot needs to pause, take a moment, look at what its doing and ask how can it best serve its clientelle - because currently, it is starting to lose sight of that.

If I may recommend you a game, I can only urge you to try SpellForce. The original trilogy anyway - Spellforce 2 and 3 (recently released) were quick to turn away from the "rune hero" concept that I enjoyed so much with the first 3 games.

The game itself is an RTS/RPG combo, offering various maps with both a 3rd person view and overhead camera option (can just scroll between them at any point). On some maps, you control just a single character, a whole army, or just you and the up to 5 rune heroes.
It's your typical beast and magic game, with 6 races available (Humans/Elves/Dwarves - Dark Elves/Trolls/Orcs), each with their own units, buildings and technologies.

At game start, you select your avatar which will be the single unit you control the whole time, and customize as you want (figher/warrior/archer/elemental-/white-/black- or mind magic sorcerer). 
Honestly, I have played this game on and off frequently since the original release back in 2003, and I still haven't tried all the varieties. 
_Not that that says much - I still haven't tried Barbarian or Necromancer in Diablo 2 either._

So far, only tried the broken things (warrior and ice elemental/healer-enchanter/death magic combo mage), so the actual balancing leaves something to be desired. Game has long since been left by the devs though.
